Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2007 05:39PM geeta75 wrote: Mom, thanks for contacting Oprah. I sure as hell hope she listens. Bimmer--I'm in. I'm way in. Let me know what needs to be done, I'm there. I stay home with the kids, so any paper pushing, phone calls, organization.....I'm yours! Look out, DC, we are COMING!!!!!! Hugs, Geeta
Posts.Title: Bimmer, I told Oprah GeetasMom GEECH

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2007 07:18PM geeta75 wrote: Oh, Wendy, you've been through the wringer--your entire family has! I have said a prayer for your darling son. I can't imagine dealing with the pain of having a child in surgery. As mothers, we would rather have the pain ourselves. It's an awful feeling, I know, to be out of control of how our babies feel. But it sounds like the worst is behind you, and he'll be up and at 'em in no time! As for the blessed with cancer thing--I agree with Katie. I am a better person, there are things in my life (ie my church, my adopted daughter, Shelli, all of YOU) that wouldn't be here if not for my diagnosis. So I kind of understand where the women on the panel were going, but honestly, "blessed" really was a poor choice of words. I certainly don't feel blessed when I go for treatments every three week, and when I live my life three months at a time between scans. Am I better for it? probably. But I'd be "blessed" if it'd never happened! I hope you can put this hellish week behind you, and get on to happier times now. I'm so sorry you have had a poopy week, but it can only get better from here. Love, Geeta
Posts.Title: What a horrible week WendyV LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2007 08:31AM geeta75 wrote: Jo, Thank you so much for asking. I'm holding my own, though my heart is beyond breaking--it's broken in two. Shelli is at peace now, and all I can do is pray for her family's hearts to heal. Love, Geeta
Posts.Title: Shelli's Obituary and Flower info geeta75 spicecakeforever

Posts.Content: geeta75 wrote: Hi, Ladies. I posted Shelli's obit in the "Shelli is and angel" thread, but sometimes things like that get a bit lost. I wanted you all to be able to read the beautiful words written for her. Also, Kimmy posted the number of a florist in Canton that will take orders for pink carnations until 10:30 eastern time tomorrow, Friday the 21st. Here is that number (thanks Kimmy--great talking to you). (330)453-0183 Shelli Kay (Hunter) Schwenk  Shelli Kay (Hunter) Schwenk Shelli Kay (Hunter) Schwenk Born November 5, 1968. Shelli passed away at home Wednesday, September 19, 2007. She will be deeply missed by the love of her life, husband Karl Schwenk, and her beautiful children: Hunter (10), Karalyn (6) and Olivia (5); parents, Stan and Sandy Hunter; father and mother-in-law, Karl and Donna Schwenk; sisters Traci (Steve) Libby, Lori (Jason) Dossi; and sister and brother-in-law Karen and Charlie Johnson. Her memory will be cherished by aunts and uncles, Barbara and Scott Brady, Debbie and Tom Beiter, Jerry and Vicky Ramsier, Gary and Joyce Hunter, Bob and Bonnie Hunter; nieces and nephews Taylor and Brianna Libby and Matthew and Leah Johnson; and countless cousins, family friends, neighbors and co-workers. She was preceded in death by her maternal grandparents, Leu and Pearl Ramsier; paternal grandparents, Clair and Helen Hunter; and uncle "Butch" Ramsier. Shelli was born in Canton, Ohio, and graduated from Lake High School in 1986. She was part of Leonard Insurance Services for 16 years, where she began as a Customer Service Rep. Shelli's spunky attitude and professionalism enabled her to become one of the first women appointed to the title of Vice President at the Leonard Agency, an accomplishment of which she was very proud. Shelli was an amazing cook and baker - her pumpkin rolls were coveted gifts for the lucky few recipients at holiday time. She and Karl enjoyed cooking together, and appreciated good food and wine. She loved to travel, and often spoke of a special trip to Europe that she and Karl made together, summer beach vacations with family, island getaways with high school buddies - and most recently a dream Disney cruise with her entire family. Through her business and personal relationships Shelli touched positively the lives of many people. This became especially true after she was diagnosed with breast cancer four years ago. Her selfless attitude, and the classy way with which she handled herself gave hope and encouragement to others. And for this, she will always be remembered. Private services for the family will be conducted on Friday with Rev. David Wright officiating. Visitation for the public will be held on Friday, September 21, 2007, in the REED FUNERAL HOME NORTH CANTON CHAPEL, 801 PITTSBURG AVE. from 2-4 and 6-8 p.m. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Aultman Hospice and Palliative Care, 2821 Woodlawn NW, Canton 44708. Those who are unable to attend and wish to share a fond memory may do so online at: http://www.reedfuneralhome.com/ Reed, 330-477-6721 Please sign the guestbook at cantonrep.com/obituaries Dx 10/1/2003, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 1/8 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Shelli's Obituary and Flower info geeta75 spicecakeforever

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2007 08:25AM geeta75 wrote: Oh, Lisa--I don't have a whole lot of knowledge with this, but I am wrapping you in a big hug--can you feel it? I don't know about WBR, but I do know of a woman (I think I may have told you this before?) that has been living with brain mets for 6 years. So you CAN and WILL see many, many, many more birthdays with your babies! I am so sorry that I don't have anything useful to add, but just know that I am thinking of you. To borrow words once said to me by a FABULOUS woman (yes, Shelli), our children are our greatest joy and our greatest sorrow. How normal it is to look at them and wonder. I know I do that every day, mine are 2 and 7. I just hope I can pull strength from them--I hope you can, too. Love, Geeta

Posts.Content: geeta75 wrote: I thought I'd start a thread for Shelli that would really make her smile. We all have different reasons for loving her, so why not let HER know? I'll start (though I have more than one reason, so bear with me! I love Shelli because she is superwoman. No doubt about it. I love Shelli because she makes me laugh--she really is a hoot! I love Shelli because she showed me hers and I showed her mine!! (we compared "frankenboobs" after reconstruction) I love Shelli because she has been my rock--not just in this fight, but also at a time when I lost a job that I would have loved--she talked me through sobbing hysterics. I love Shelli because, no matter what she was going through, she was always worried about me. I love Shelli because she's so darn smart. That girl has a fabulous head on her shoulders. I love Shelli because she doesn't like flying, either! I love Shelli because she is a wine lover like me! (We shared a rediculously expensive bottle at Capital Grille in Philly--she never did let me see that bill.....) I love Shelli because she makes beautiful babies! :) I love Shelli because she loves me, she helps me, she cries with me, she laughs with me, she understands me, she supports me, she KNOWS me--she's just my Shelli. Your turn. Dx 10/1/2003, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 1/8 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: I love Shelli because....... geeta75 rue2u

Posts.Content: geeta75 wrote: It is through tears and with a broken heart that I bring you this news. Our beautiful Shelli passed away early this morning. Her pain has ended, and her family can now begin to heal. Sandy is doing ok, I know you all worry about her as well. My prayers go out to Sandy, Stan, Karl, Hunter, Kara, and Olivia. May the Lord help them heal and continue to carry Shelli's legacy. And may Shelli look down on us, and smile with us when we're happy, cry with us when we're sad, and hold our hand when we feel alone. Shelli asked me to let you all know that any donations that you may want to make in her memory, regardless of what the paper says, should be made to breastcancer.org. She pulled so much strength from this site, and your love helped her through her darkest days. This is her wish, so I wanted to pass it on. I am going to try to post a picture--Shelli's avatar that you all know and love so much. You need to see it upclose, to really see what a gorgeous woman Shelli was, inside and out. Forgive me if it does not show up, I've never done this before. I am also adding one of my favorite pictures of Shelli and I from 2005 in Philadelphia. This is how I want to remember her--with the family she loves, and all smiles and hugs with me. God, I miss her already. I don't know what else to say. I'm broken...... Love, Geeta " mce_src="" alt="" border="" hspace="" vspace="" width="" height="" align="" /> " mce_src="" alt="" border="" hspace="" vspace="" width="" height="" align="" /> Dx 10/1/2003, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 1/8 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2008 07:39AM - edited Oct 2, 2008 07:43AM by geeta75 Hi, Stack. I am pretty much MIA from the boards for months at a time, but I just happened to pop in today and saw your post. My elbow began hurting, felt like I had cracked it up against a wall, and was very bruised feeling to the touch. My onc thought it was tendonitis, nothing to be concerned about, but we went through the scans to verify--had an xray, mri, ct, and finally a bone biopsy. That is when it was determined that I did indeed have mets.  Nowhere else in the bones, just my elbow! I do, incidentally, also have lung mets. The xray showed nothing, and my bloodwork has always been normal. The only 100% definite test was the CT guided bone biopsy. Hurt like hell, but it was at least the answer I needed (although not at all the one I wanted) When I received radiation to the site, my radiation onc at the Cleveland Clinic said she had never treated an elbow before. So while rare, it is possible. BUT--that said, with your prior elbow issues, I'm certain it truly is nothing. But please get every scan under the sun until it is determined beyond the shadow of a doubt that it is NOTHING to worry about, ok? Good luck to you, I'll keep you in my prayers. Pam--you are the only other person I've ever heard of with elbow mets! And I thought I was the only goofed up one out there...  :) Hugs, Geeta

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2007 10:45PM geeta75 wrote: Hi, I'm still here!!! Traci, thank you for letting me know about this thread. And Julie---I am touched just about to tears (okay, so I AM in tears!) that you thought of me. Thank you from the top and bottom of my heart. I am doing quite well, and I apologize for being MIA for so long. I guess after all that has happened over the past few months (Shelli) I just kind of needed a break. But you all have never been far from my mind, nor absent from my heart. Please know that that is true. I love you ALL so very much! Traci does keep me posted on what is going on here. Some of it is happy, and some is hard to hear. But I'm grateful to have that "lifeline" to you all. Traci, I'm not actually NED (though WOW, wouldn't THAT be wonderful!!), but I have had tumor shrinkage for the first time since my stage 4 diagnosis!!! Whoopeeeeeee! So I'm relishing in the moment, at least until January when I am due for more scans. I keep in touch still with Sandy (Shelli's mom), and actually had a lunch date scheduled with her last week, but she came down with a horrible cold, and it was snowing pretty steadily all day, so we had to cancel. But she still peeks on you guys every now and then to see how you are. You have all become a part of her as well. Just wanted to let you know. Again, thank you thank you thank you for thinking of me. I'm loving life right now, and am trying to hang on to that for as long as I can. I love you all very much!!!! If I don't pop in again soon, have a wonderful, fabulous, happy, joyous, laughter filled, obnoxiously Merry Christmas!!!! Please take care of yourselves, ok? Love and great big hugs, Geeta

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2007 10:40PM geeta75 wrote: Oh, I am so sorry you have had to deal with the ignorance of this lady!! I guess it IS hard for others to understand "disabled," when so many of us still look like the picture of health. Had you told her that you have stage 4 cancer, I'm sure she would have been singing another tune! I probably would have told her about my disability, and added that what's creepy is that she's been watching you for a week....  :) I know it's easier said than done, but don't let her ruin another day. Just chalk it up to ignorance. And unfortunately, you can't always tell by looking at someone that they are sick, or disabled. Take it as a compliment!! You look marvelous!! Now I once saw a MAN get into his car that was parked in the "pregnant mother" parking...........no gettin' around that one. He was just an a$$! Love to you, Geeta
Posts.Title: Do I have to look disabled? Fllorik Fllorik

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2007 10:27PM geeta75 wrote: Omacar--I'm hugging you so tight right now!!! According to "statistics," I'm already dead. And yet I sit here and type..... Please don't put all of your faith in the scientific documentations of how long, or short, we are expected to live. The great news is, your disease is STABLE, and your labs are ok!!!! That's something to relish in. I hate that you are in this funk as well. You sound so very down, and I hope you have someone you can talk to. Sometimes anti-depressants are just the pick me up that you need in times like this. No one expects us to be "strong" all the time. You're entitled to weak moments, I just pray that they aren't the only moments you have. Please try to keep your chin up (I know, easier said than done) and don't think you're going anywhere anytime soon! Ok?? Love to you, Geeta
Posts.Title: feeling down tracey2424 joanne1428

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2007 04:12PM geeta75 wrote: Hi, Tracy! You know, it honestly only took me a couple of weeks to feel better about my mets--but it is most likely because I had suspected mets for about 7 months prior to diagnosis. I have lung and bone mets, and during routine scans, tiny spots were found on my lungs, too small to biopsy, or radiate--measured in milimeters, not centimeters. They weren't sure if they were mets, or fighting an infection, or scarring--so we just waited, but I think I knew. Then when I lost mobility in my right arm, a bone biopsy confirmed bone mets, and we've confirmed the lung since. So I guess I was happily in denial land for a few months, but had a bit of time to get used to it. Once it was confirmed that I was metastatic, it was a couple weeks of BLECH before I put on my boxing gloves again. And I'm really and truly ok now. I have my moments, but even completely healthy people have times when they want to scream ENOUGH ALREADY!! It's not easy, but you really can get your life back. I hate that you are so down, but I know that you can do this! You can pull out of this sorrow--but give it time. And don't you dare ever feel guilty about being depressed. You're entitled! Also--if you feel that you need it, many, many, many women here have been on anti-depressants, especially around the time of diagnosis. It's a difficult time that no one should have to face, but there are medications that can help you if you need them. Just a thought. Keep us posted on how you are. The emotional side of this disease is just as hard as the physical. Love, Geeta PS--Badboob--I LOOOOVE it!! SCANIC!! I'll have to use that one....

Posts.Title: Shelli is an angel geeta75 Sige

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2007 12:31PM - edited Sep 23, 2007 12:33PM by geeta75 Ozzie, I don't like the attitude your onc is taking with you!!! Shame on him. Of COURSE it matters where the cancer is--it matters to YOU, and damn it, that's ALL that matters!!!! I could just shake him..... My onc typically relies on my scans, we do a PET and CAT every three months, and occasionally an MRI if needed. The CAT shows any new masses, or growths, and the PET shows new cellular activity, even if it hasn't formed a tumor and shown up on the CAT. My meds were switched last scan because, even though the CAT showed no change, a couple of new areas of increased metabolic activity lit up on the PET. So we figured we'd nip it in the bud quickly. I don't have my tumor markers relayed to me. I guess if they skyrocketed it would be brought to my attention, but truly I have no desire to see them. I guess it's because they can change so often, and aren't really terribly accurate all the time. But my scans are pretty well right on. I really want you to consider getting a different onc. I STRONGLY dislike the way you are being treated. You do not deserve to be blown off, treated poorly, and left in the dark. Everything should be explained to you in terms you can understand!!! I really, really want to shake him---hard. Ask these questions point blank to your onc. And then take these same questions, with all of your medical records/scans, to another onc that will treat you like you deserve to be treated. Good luck, sweetie. Love, Geeta PS By the way, NO question is a silly question!!!

Posts.Title: Shelli is an angel geeta75 Sige

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2007 05:48AM geeta75 wrote: Hi Tracey--just checking in on you. Feeling better? i hope your funk is over, and you're happily chugging along again. HUGS! Love, Geeta
Posts.Title: feeling down tracey2424 joanne1428

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2007 10:28PM geeta75 wrote: Omacar--I'm hugging you so tight right now!!! According to "statistics," I'm already dead. And yet I sit here and type..... Please don't put all of your faith in the scientific documentations of how long, or short, we are expected to live. The great news is, your disease is STABLE, and your labs are ok!!!! That's something to relish in. I hate that you are in this funk as well. You sound so very down, and I hope you have someone you can talk to. Sometimes anti-depressants are just the pick me up that you need in times like this. No one expects us to be "strong" all the time. You're entitled to weak moments, I just pray that they aren't the only moments you have. Please try to keep your chin up (I know, easier said than done) and don't think you're going anywhere anytime soon! Ok?? Love to you, Geeta
Posts.Title: feeling down tracey2424 joanne1428

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2007 09:13PM geeta75 wrote: Kenna, I hate that you are here with us, but elated that the support these awesome women offer has already lifted your spirits. Please keep coming back, ok? Love, Geeta
